bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: As a youth Rogers attended Weaver High School, where he was the first black student to be elected captain of the football team. He retired in 1968 after 40 years with the U.S. Postal Service. The first black to land a job with the Hartford post office, Rogers' last post was postmaster of the Bishops Corner, West Hartford, office. He was awarded an honorary doctorate in humane letters in 1970 from the University of Hartford and taught the first black history course at the University of Hartford.

In 1976, Rogers wrote the Inner City Bicentennial Booklet, which told the achievements of blacks during the 1700s, and was distributed to Connecticut inner city youngsters. He was the recipient of many awards, most notably the first St. Benedict Award from the Catholic Interracial Council of Hartford, the Charter Oak Leadership Medal of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, and the Thurgood Marshall Award fo the NAACP. Dr. Rogers served on the boards of of many civic organizations, including the Community Renewal Team of Greater Hartford, the Urban League and the Hartford Neighborhood Center.

The Dr. John E. Rogers Memorial Library was opened on Main Street in Hartford in 1977, the same year that Rogers was named to the Freedom of Information Commission by Gov. Ella T. Grasso. He served until ill health forced him to resign in 1981. Dr Rogers passed away on Friday, May 28, 1982 at the age of 75.

Dr. Floyd Bass, professor in the UConn School of Education, was appointed as the research assistant for the Center for Black Studies, the predecessor of the Institute for African American Studies. Launched in June 1969, the Center was established as the result of a committee of faculty, administrators and students proposal. The committee requested an operating budget to cover colloquia, travel, temporary assistance, research assistants, library acquisition and printing. A personnel budget covered permanent positions for a director, secretary and five positions for newly hired Black faculty members. Dr. Bass was assigned as the Center's Research Assistant in accordance with a pilot plan for attracting Black scholars to the University. By 1976, Dr. Bass had been appointed director of the Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains framed clippings, a framed novelty song collection, a framed book collection, a framed honorary degree, and research posters.
